title: Hiram Scofield
text:
Hiram Scofield (July 1, 1830 – December 30, 1906) was a <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a> and <a href="Union%20Army">Union Army</a> officer during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. He entered the Army as a <a href="private%20%28rank%29">private</a> in 1861 and was discharged as a <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20States%29">colonel</a> on January 5, 1866. In February 1866 he was nominated by <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">President</a> <a href="Andrew%20Johnson">Andrew Johnson</a> for appointment to the rank of <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> of volunteers and the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> confirmed the appointment in April 1866.
Early life and career.
Scofield was born in rural <a href="Saratoga%20County%2C%20New%20York">Saratoga County, New York</a>. He attended <a href="Union%20College">Union College</a> and graduated from <a href="Albany%20Law%20School">Albany Law School</a> in 1856. He established a law practice in <a href="Washington%2C%20Iowa">Washington, Iowa</a>, in 1858.
Civil War.
Scofield enlisted as a private in the Union Army in April 1861 and was assigned to Company H of the <a href="2nd%20Iowa%20Infantry">2nd Iowa Infantry</a>. He was promoted to <a href="second%20lieutenant">second</a> and then to <a href="First%20Lieutenant%23United%20States">first lieutenant</a>, taking command of the company in February 1862 at the time of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Fort%20Donelson">Battle of Fort Donelson</a>. He was adjudant to Brig. Gen. <a href="Jacob%20Gartner%20Lauman">Jacob G. Lauman</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Shiloh">Battle of Shiloh</a> where Scofield was wounded in the leg. He returned to duty within a month. He was transferred to the staff of Brig. Gen. <a href="John%20McArthur">John McArthur</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Vicksburg">Battle of Vicksburg</a> and the <a href="Battle%20of%20Memphis">Battle of Memphis</a>.
In spring of 1863, Scofield organized and commanded the <a href="8th%20Louisiana%20Regiment%20Infantry%20%28African%20Descent%29">8th Louisiana Regiment Infantry (African Descent)</a> at <a href="Lake%20Providence%2C%20Louisiana">Lake Providence, Louisiana</a>. The regiment participated in the expedition up the <a href="Yazoo%20River">Yazoo River</a>. In the spring of 1864, he was assigned to command the 2nd Brigade of Maj. Gen. <a href="Edward%20Canby">Edward Canby</a>'s <a href="Division%20%28military%29">division</a>. The <a href="regiment">regiment</a> was transferred to <a href="Pensacola%2C%20Florida">Pensacola, Florida</a>, and then participated in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Fort%20Blakely">Battle of Fort Blakely</a> and the capture of <a href="Mobile%2C%20Alabama">Mobile, Alabama</a>. Scofield and his men thereafter were stationed in <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a> and <a href="Texas">Texas</a>.
Scofield was mustered out of the volunteers on January 5, 1866. On February 24, 1866, President Andrew Johnson nominated Scofield for appointment to the grade of <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20States%29">brigadier general</a> of volunteers, to rank from March 13, 1865, and the United States Senate confirmed the appointment on April 10, 1866.
Postbellum activities.
After the Civil War, Scofield resumed his law practice in Iowa, which he continued until his death in 1906 in <a href="Seattle%2C%20Washington">Seattle, Washington</a>.
Hiram Scofield held "one of the largest private libraries in the nation. After his death his personal library was split between the cities of Washington and Wellman."
